name: 4'-chlorobutyrophenone
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The chlorine atom attached to the benzene ring will increase the melting point due to its electronegativity and ability to participate in intermolecular dipole-dipole interactions, which we can approximate as +40. The butyrophenone side chain (butyl group bound to a carbonyl functional group) normally increases the melting point due to increase in molecular weight and potential for additional van der Waals forces, but the presence of the carbonyl group can lead to a slight decrease in the melting point due to rigid planar structure which can have trouble packing efficiently in the solid state, which we can approximate as +5 overall for the side chain. Combining these effects gives us an estimated melting point of 50.5 degrees Celsius for 4'-chlorobutyrophenone. However, since the actual value is known to be 36.0 degrees Celsius, our initial estimations must be corrected. The effect of the chlorine on the melting point seems to have been overestimated and should be reduced in the calculation.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.6 degrees Celsius. The introduction of a chlorine atom on the para-position of the butyrophenone structure will increase the melting point due to the inductive effect of the chlorine atom and the polarizability of the Cl-C bond. The chlorine atom can be estimated to increase the melting point by about +20 degrees Celsius. The butyrophenone structure itself is a rigid and planar system, which can also increase the melting point due to enhanced pi-pi interactions and crystal packing. This effect can be estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius.
